type.desc: Set the data transformation type to sankey for calculating sankey layout

direction.desc:
The layout direction of the Sankey diagram, default value is horizontal, optional values are:

  • 'horizontal' sets the layout direction to horizontal
  • 'vertical' sets the layout direction to vertical

nodeAlign.desc:
Set the alignment of nodes in the same level, optional values are:

  • 'left' if the layout direction is horizontal, align nodes to the left, if the layout direction is vertical, align nodes to the top
  • 'right' if the layout direction is horizontal, align nodes to the right, if the layout direction is vertical, align nodes to the bottom
  • 'center' align nodes to the center
  • 'justify' align nodes to both ends
  • 'start' same meaning as 'left'
  • 'end' same meaning as 'right'

nodeGap.desc: Set the gap size between nodes in the same level

nodeWidth.desc:
Set the width of the nodes. If the layout direction is vertical, this value corresponds to the node's height, and supports three types of values:

    1. string percentage string, e.g. { nodeWidth: '12%' }
    1. number simple number, in px, e.g. { nodeWidth: 20 }
    1. function function, custom calculation of node width

linkWidth.desc: Specify the width of the edges between nodes, in px; if the layout direction is vertical, this value corresponds to the height of the edge; This value can be unset, and if unset, a suitable value will be calculated based on the number of levels

minStepWidth.desc: The minimum width ( = single node width + single edge width) corresponding to each level; if the layout is vertical, this value corresponds to the height; If not set, a suitable value will be calculated based on the number of nodes; For special layout scenarios, it is recommended to use this property in conjunction with a scrollbar when displaying the graph

minNodeHeight.desc:
For non-empty nodes, set the minimum node height, in px; if the layout is vertical, this value corresponds to the width;

This configuration mainly solves the problem that the node height will be very small when the data is very small, making it hard to see the node;

It is recommended not to set this value too large, generally not more than 5

minLinkHeight.desc: Set the minimum height of the link, in px; if the layout is vertical, this value corresponds to the width; This configuration mainly solves the problem that the link height will be very small when the data is very small, making it hard to see the link; It is recommended not to set this value too large, generally not more than 5 Can be used in conjunction with minNodeHeight; it is recommended that this value be less than the value set for minNodeHeight

iterations.desc: Set the number of iterations for the layout calculation, the more iterations, the more accurate the layout calculation result, but the calculation time will also be longer

nodeKey.desc: Type: string|number Set the field corresponding to the globally unique key of the node, if not set, it will be generated internally based on the level and other information

linkSortBy.desc: Set the edge sorting function, if not set, no sorting will be done on the edge-related data

nodeSortBy.desc: Set the node sorting function, if not set, no sorting will be done on the node data

setNodeLayer.desc: Custom set the node to ultimately display in which level, no need to set by default, only need to set for special customization needs
